questions.text: A 10 year old boy presented with abdominal pain, muscle weakness and fatigue. On investigations , serum lead levels were found increased in blood . Activity of which of the following enzyme in the liver is increased :
questions.solution: A Ref.: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 28/e p272, 278 High levels of lead can affect heme metabolism by combining with SH groups in enzymes such as ferrochelatase and ALA dehydratase. This affects porphyrin metabolism. Elevated levels of protoporphyrin are found in red blood cells, and elevated levels of ALA and of coproporphyrin are found in urine.

questions.text: If in a person total cholesterol =300 mg/dl , HDL, = 25 mg/dl and triglycerides = 150 mg/dl , what will be the LDL levels
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: In a person , serum LDL level are highly elevated but the number of LDL receptor is normal . What could be the probable cause
questions.solution: B Ref.: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 28/e p232

questions.text: A 7 year old by presents with severe abdominal pain . On examination he has xanthomas. A sample of blood was drawn which had milky appearance. Which lipoprotein is likely to be raised
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A Case of Type 1 hyperlipoproteinemia due to lipoprotein lipase deficiency. Ref.: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 28th/e p 231 -233

questions.text: What does forward scatter in flow cytometry denote
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- (B) Ref.: Http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/flow_cytometryhttp;// bitesizebio.com/13695/basic- measurements-of flow cytometer - forward - side scatter-quantitative-flow-cytometry When the laser beam strikes the stream, the majority of the photons will pass through unobstructed. Some of these photons will diverge slightly, primarily via light diffraction, from their path as they contact the membranes of passing cells. A detector is placed in line with the laser path (on the opposite side of the stream) and this “scattered” light is collected. Because of the nature of its collection, this parameter is referred to as Small Angle Light Scatter (SALS), Forward Angle Lights Scatter (FALS), or, most commonly, Forward Scatter (FSC). Forward scatter is proportional to cell size; the bigger the cell, the more light is scattered, the higher the detected signal. As cells are translucent, many photons will pass through the cytoplasm. If the photon strikes an organelle (ER, nucleus, etc), the photon will be reflected at a larger angle than those generated by the forward scatter phenomenon. In a typical cytometer, a second detector is placed perpendicular to the laser path to collect light scattered in this manner. This is known as Wide Angle Light Scatter (WALS), Orthogonal Light Scatter (OLS), 90° Lights Scatter, or, commonly, Side Scatter (SSC). Side scatter is proportional to cell complexity; the more organelles/bits inside the cytoplasm, the more light scatter, the higher the detected signal.

questions.text: In gene studies, the specific site to which the enzyme CRE recombinase binds is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cre-Lox recombination is a site-specific recombinase technology, used to carry out deletions, insertions, translocations and inversions at specific sites in the DNA of cells. It allows the DNA modification to be targeted to a specific cell type or be triggered by a specific external stimulus. It is implemented both in eukaryotic and prokaryotic systems. The Cre-lox recombination system has been particularly useful to help neuroscientists to study the brain in which complex cell types and neural circuits come together to generate cognition and behaviors. NIH Blueprint for Neuroscience Research has created several hundreds of Cre driver mouse lines which are currently used by the worldwide neuroscience community. The system consists of a single enzyme, Cre recombinase, that recombines a pair of short target sequences called the Lox sequences. This system can be implemented without inserting any extra supporting proteins or sequences. The Cre enzyme and the original Lox site called the LoxP sequence are derived from bacteriophage P1. Placing Lox sequences appropriately allows genes to be activated, repressed, or exchanged for other genes. At a DNA level many types of manipulations can be carried out. The activity of the Cre enzyme can be controlled so that it is expressed in a particular cell type or triggered by an external stimulus like a chemical signal or a heat shock. These targeted DNA changes are useful in cell lineage tracing and when mutants are lethal if expressed globally.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is involved in both glycogenesis and glycogenolysis pathways
questions.solution: B Ref.: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 28/e p 158

questions.text: During fasting state, for metabolism red blood cells will use
questions.solution: A Ref.: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 28/e p141 (table )

questions.text: RNAi causes the following in a gene
questions.solution: Correct Answer C Ref.: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RNA_interference the term RNA interference (RNAi) was coined to describe a cellular mechanism that use the gene's own DNA sequence of gene to turn it off, a process that researchers call silencing. In a wide variety of organisms, including animals, plants, and fungi, RNAi is triggered by double-stranded RNA (dsRNA).

questions.text: Thiamine deficiency causes lactic acidosis due to dysfunction of which enzyme
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ref.: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 28/e p 468, 473 Thiamine Coenzyme in pyruvate and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenases, and transketolase; regulates Cl−channel in nerve conduction Peripheral nerve damage (beriberi) or central nervous system lesions (Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome)

questions.text: What is the codon for selenocysteine :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) UGA Ref: Harper: Illustrated Biochemistry 30/e p 18, 286 Selenocysteine is an l-α-amino acid found in a handful of proteins, including certain peroxidases and reductases where it participates in the catalysis of electron transfer reactions. As its name implies, a selenium atom replaces the sulfur of its structural analog, cysteine. The pK3 of selenocysteine, 5.2, is 3 units lower than that of cysteine. Since selenocysteine is inserted into polypeptides during translation, it is commonly referred to as the “21st amino acid.” selenocysteine arises co-translationally during its incorporation into peptides. The UGA anticodon of the unusual tRNA designated tRNASec normally signals STOP. The ability of the protein synthetic apparatus to identify a selenocysteine-specific UGA codon involves the selenocysteine insertion element, a stem-loop structure in the untranslated region of the mRNA.

questions.text: Biotin is not required as a cofactor in which of these reactions :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A Gamma carboxylation of glutamate (vitamin K dependent) Ref: Harper: Illustrated Biochemistry 30/e p561 Biotin Is a Coenzyme of Carboxylase Enzymes Biotin functions to transfer carbon dioxide in a small num ber of reactions: acetyl-CoA carboxylase .pyruvate carboxylase , propionyl-CoA carbox ylase), and methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase. A holocarboxylase synthetase catalyzes the transfer of biotin onto a lysine residue of the apo-enzyme to form the bioctin residue of the holoenzyme. The reactive intermediate is 1-N-carboxy biocytin, formed from bicarbonate in an ATP dependent reaction. The carboxyl group is then transferred to the substrate for carboxylation Biotin also has a role in regulation of the cell cycle, acting to biotinylate key nuclear proteins,

questions.text: Which of the following is not a technique for protein precipitation:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Titration with reducing sugar Ref: Harper: Illustrated Biochemistry 30/e p26 Selective precipitation exploits differences in relative solubility of individual proteins as a function of pH (isoelectric precipitation), polarity (precipitation with ethanol or acetone), or salt concentration (salting out with ammonium sulfate). Chromatographic techniques separate one protein from another based upon difference in their size (size exclusion chromatography), charge (ion-exchange chromatography), hydrophobicity (hydrophobic interaction chromatography), or ability to bind a specific ligand (affinity chromatography).

questions.text: Which of these is not a cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase (an important enzyme of the glycogenolysis pathway) :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Glycogenin Ref: Harper: Illustrated Biochemistry 30/e p 181

questions.text: After a point mutation glutamic acid is replaced by valine which leads to formation of sickle cell hemoglobin .the mobility of HbS as compared with normal hemoglobin on electrophoresis will be :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Decreased Ref: Harper: Illustrated Biochemistry 30/e p460 Sickle-cell disease, which is caused by mutation of a single base out of the 3 × 109 in the genome, a T-to-A DNA substitution, which in turn results in an A-to-U change in the mRNA corresponding to the sixth codon of the β-globin gene. The altered codon specifies a different amino acid (valine rather than glutamic acid), and this causes a structural abnormality of the β-globin molecule leading to hemoglobin aggregation and red blood cell “sickling.”

questions.text: Thiamine is a cofactor for all of the following enzymes except :
questions.solution: Correct (C) Succinate dehydrogenase ( FADdependent enzyme) Ref: Harper: Illustrated Biochemistry 30/e p555 TPP works as a coenzyme in many enzymatic reactions, such as: Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex Pyruvate decarboxylase in ethanol fermentation Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex Branched-chain amino acid dehydrogenase complex 2-hydroxyphytanoyl-CoA lyase Transketolase

questions.text: The cofactor vitamin B 12 is required for the following conversion :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Methylmalonyl CoA to succinyl CoA (Also for homocysteine to methionine via methionine synthase) Ref: Harper: Illustrated Biochemistry 30/e p 550 Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase (MCM), mitochondrial, also known as methylmalonyl-CoA isomerase, is a protein that in humans is encoded by the MUT gene. This vitamin B12-dependent enzyme catalyzes the isomerization of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA in humans. Mutations in MUT gene may lead to various types of methylmalonic aciduria. Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is expressed in high concentrations in the kidney, in intermediate concentrations in the heart, ovaries, brain, muscle, and liver, and in low concentrations in the spleen. The enzyme can be found all throughout the central nervous system (CNS). MCM resides in the mitochondria, where a number of substances, including the branched-chain amino acids isoleucine and valine, as well as methionine, threonine, thymine and odd-chain fatty acids, are metabolized via methylmalonate semialdehyde (MMlSA) or propionyl-CoA (Pr-CoA) to a common compound - methylmalonyl-CoA (MMl-CoA). MCM catalyzes the reversible isomerisation of l?methylmalonyl?CoA to succinyl?CoA, requiring cobalamin (vitamin B12) in the form of adenosylcobalamin (AdoCbl) as a cofactor.

choices.text: The thermodynamics does not favor such a reaction to occur
Glucose - 6- phosphatase is present in the endoplasmic reticulum and cannot act on glycogen formed in the cytoplasm
Glycogenesis and glycogenolysis are tightly regulated such that enzymes of only one of those is present at a time

questions.text: Glycogen synthesis and breakdown takes place in the same cell having enzymes necessary for both the path ways . Why is the glucose 6 phosphate , freshly synthesized during glycogenesis in cytoplasm of hepatocytes is not immediately degraded by the enzyme glucose 6 phosphatase :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ref: Harper: Illustrated Biochemistry 30/e p 178 Glucose-6-phosphatase catalyzes hydrolysis of glucose-6-phosphate, yielding glucose that is exported, leading to an increase in the blood glucose concentration. Glucose-6-phosphatase is in the lumen of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum, and genetic defects of the glucose-6-phosphate transporter can cause a variant of type I glycogen storage disease.

questions.text: All of these substrates are glucogenic except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The major substrates of gluconeogenesis are lactate, glycerol, and glucogenic amino acids.

questions.text: Sites of heme synthesis are all of these except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) RBC Ref: Harper: Illustrated Biochemistry 30/e p325 85% of heme synthesis occurs in erythroid precursor cells in the bone marrow, and the majority of the remainder in hepatocytes.

questions.text: A child to emergency with accidental ingestion of Cyanide. It blocks citric acid cycle by blocking:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) NAD+ Ref: Harper:Illustrated Biochemistry 30/ep132 The classic poisons H2S, carbon monoxide, and cyanide inhibit Complex IV and can therefore totally arrest respiration. Cyanide blocks citric acid cycle by inhibiting NAD+.

questions.text: Which type of lipase is controlled by glucagon:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hormone sensitive lipase Ref: Harper: IllustratedBiochemistry30/e p262 Hormone-sensitive lipase is activated by ACTH, TSH, glucagon, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and vasopressin and inhibited by insulin, prostaglandin E1, and nicotinic acid.

questions.text: In The Mammalian Genome,maximum number of genes code for receptors:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Diverse odorant molecules in the environment are detected by olfactory receptors (ORs) expressed in the olfactory epithelium of the nasal cavity. In general, mammalian genomes harbor ~1,000 OR genes, which form the largest multigene family in mammals. The recent advances in genome sequencing technology have enabled us to computationally identify nearly complete repertoires of OR genes from various organisms. Such studies have revealed that the numbers of OR genes are highly variable among organisms depending on their living environments. Because OR genes are intronless, it is possible to find all OR genes by conducting homology searches against the genome sequences using known OR genes as queries.

questions.text: second messenger for smooth muscle relaxation mediated by NO is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) cGMP Ref: Harper:Illustratedbiochemistry30/ep660 Cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) is a cyclic nucleotide derived from guanosine triphosphate (GTP). cGMP acts as a second messenger much like cyclic AMP. Its most likely mechanism of action is activation of intracellular protein kinases in response to the binding of membrane-impermeable peptide hormones to the external cell surface. cGMP is a common regulator of ion channel conductance, glycogenolysis, and cellular apoptosis. It also relaxes smooth muscle tissues. In blood vessels, relaxation of vascular smooth muscles lead to vasodilation and increased blood flow.

Chromatographic techniques separate one protein from another based upon difference in their size (size exclusion chromatography), charge (ion-exchange chromatography), hydrophobicity (hydrophobic interaction chromatography), or ability to bind a specific ligand (affinity chromatography).

Modifier can affect the catalytic site by binding to the allosteric
Adding more substrate to the enzyme can displace the allosteric modifier

questions.text: About the following Michael is – Menten curve ,true statement is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Modifier can affect the catalytic site by binding to the allosteric Ref: Harper: Illustrated Biochemistry30/ep 80,91 Allosteric enzymes are distinguished by their response to changes in substrate concentration in addition to their susceptibility to regulation by other molecules. Allosteric enzymes display a sigmoidal dependence of reaction velocity on substrate concentration in contrast to the hyperbolic curve seen with Michaelis-Menten enzymes.

questions.text: During starvation, graph of three substances are plotted as below. The Scale for A and B is on the left and the scale for C is on the right. Which of the substances are represented by the curve B?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) RT3 Ref: Ganong 24/e pg 345 Most pronounced effect of starvation on thyroid profile is a reduction in T3 levels with a reciprocal rise in RT3. The changes, which conserve calories by reducing tissue metabolism, are reversed promptly by refeeding. Similar changes occur in wasting diseases

questions.text: All of these processes take place in mitochondria except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Fatty acid synthesis Ref: Harper 30/e 232 Fatty acids are synthesized by an extramitochondrial system, which is responsible for the complete synthesis of palmitate from acetyl-CoA in the cytosol.

questions.text: Which of these is most effective for gluconeogenesis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acety-CoA stimulation of pyruvate carboxylase synthesis of oxaloacetate from pyruvate, requires acetyl-CoA as an allosteric activator. The addition of acetyl-CoA results in a change in the tertiary structure of the protein, lowering the Km for bicarbonate. This means that as acetyl-CoA is formed from pyruvate, it automatically ensures the provision of oxaloacetate and, therefore, its further oxidation in the citric acid cycle, by activating pyruvate carboxylase. The activation of pyruvate carboxylase and the reciprocal inhibition of pyruvate dehydrogenase by acetyl-CoA derived from the oxidation of fatty acids explain the action of fatty acid oxidation in sparing the oxidation of pyruvate (and hence glucose) and in stimulating gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: Which vitamin is synthesized in vivo in the body by humans?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Niacin Niacin was discovered as a nutrient during studies of pellagra. It is not strictly a vitamin since it can be synthesized in the body from the essential amino acid tryptophan. Two compounds, nicotinic acid and nicotinamide, have the biological activity of niacin; its metabolic function is as the nicotinamide ring of the coenzymes NAD and NADP in oxidation/reduction reactions. Some 60 mg of tryptophan is equivalent to 1 mg of dietary niacin. The niacin content of foods is expressed as mg niacin equivalents = mg preformed niacin + 1/60 × mg tryptophan. Since most of the niacin in cereals is biologically unavailable, this is discounted.

questions.text: A patient has normal blood glucose level as estimated by Glucose-Oxidase peroxidse method, shows positive Benedicts test in urine. Which of the following is likely cause?"
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) While the glucose oxidase strip test is specific for Glucose, Benedict's test is positive for all reducing sugars, including Glucose, galactose, and fructose. Since, There's nothing like fructosemia (water soluble excreted in urine) only viable option remaining is Galactosemia.

questions.text: Which of these is the correct representation of the normal oral glucose tolerance test?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Graph A: Correct representation of normal oral glucose tolerance test Graph B: Excessively rapid carbohydrate absorption Graph C: Liver disease Ref: Ganong 24/e pg 448

questions.text: CG islands in our DNA are important for:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Methylation Ref: Haprper 30/e pg 735 Methylation of cytosine to form 5′methylcytosine. The cytosine is usually located next to a guanine residue, forming a CpG island. Methylation of cytosine by a methyltransferase is associated with silencing of the activities of certain genes.

questions.text: Which of these is the best test for assessment of intestinal malabsorption?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) D-xylose absorption test Ref: Harrison’s 18/e chap 294 The N-benzoyl-L-tyrosyl-p-aminobenzoic acid test, a noninvasive test primarily used to measure the function of the exocrine pancreas. The test is performed by administering NBT-PABA to patients with suspected chronic pancreatitis and measuring the amount of PABA excreted in the urine. In patients with chronic pancreatitis, chymotrypsin is not released by the exocrine pancreas into the gastrointestinal tract; NBT is not cleaved from PABA, and thus the excretion of PABA in the urine is diminished.

questions.text: The pH of a solution containing 5 millimole per liter of H+ ions is closest to what value?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 2.3 Here, pH can be calculated using - pH =-log[H+] pH= -log[5*10^-3] = -log(5) - log(l0^-3 ) = -log(l0/2) +3 = -1 + log2 +3 = 2 +0.3010 = 2.3

questions.text: Ammonia from brain is removed as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Glutamine Ref: Harper 30/e pg 292 Formation of glutamine is catalyzed by mitochondrial glutamine synthase. Since amide bond synthesis is coupled to the hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and Pi, the reaction strongly favors glutamine synthesis. During catalysis, glutamate attacks the γ-phosphoryl group of ATP, forming γ-glutamyl phosphate and ADP. Following deprotonation of NH4 +, NH3 attacks γ-glutamyl phosphate, and glutamine and Pi are released. In addition to providing glutamine to serve as a carrier of nitrogen, carbon and energy between organs, glutamine synthase plays a major role in ammonia detoxification and acid-base homeostasis. A rare deficiency in neonate glutamine synthase results in severe brain damage, multiorgan failure, and death.

questions.text: RQ of a person on pure carbohydrate diet will be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1 R.Q. of Carbohydrates is 1, protein is 0.8, fat is 0.7 Ref: Harper 30/e pg 148 The respiratory quotient (or RQ or respiratory coefficient), is a dimensionless number used in calculations of basal metabolic rate (BMR) when estimated from carbon dioxide production. It is calculated from the ratio of carbon dioxide produced by the body to oxygen consumed by the body.

questions.text: Which of the following is maximum in HDL as compared to other lipoproteins?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Apoproteins Ref: Harper 30/e pg 254

questions.text: Common intermediate in synthesis of steroid hormones is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pregnenolone Ref: Harper 30/e pg 503 Upon stimulation of the adrenal by ACTH, an esterase is activated, and the free cholesterol formed is transported into the mitochondrion, where a cytochrome P450 side chain cleavage enzyme (P450scc) converts cholesterol to pregnenolone.

questions.text: At physiological pH, which of these amino acids has a positive charge?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Arginine Ref: Harper 30/e pg 21

questions.text: HCO3/H2CO3 is the best buffer because it is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Its components can be increased or decreased in the body as needed. HCO3/H2CO3 is the best buffer because its components can be increased or decreased in the body as needed. Bicarbonate ion secretion and reabsorption is regulated by the kidneys while carbonic acid (CO2) levels are maintained by the respiratory.

choices.text: Conversion of pyruvate to lactic acid
Conversion of pyruvate to acetyl co A

questions.text: Which of the following is anaplerotic reaction?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Conversion pyruvate to oxaloacetate Ref. DM Vasudevan, Textbook of Biochemistry for medical Students 7thed, page 253 Anaplerotic reactions are chemical reactions that form intermediates of a metabolic pathway. Examples of such are found in the citric acid cycle (TCA cycle). In normal function of this cycle for respiration, concentrations of TCA intermediates remain constant; however, many biosynthetic reactions also use these molecules as a substrate. Anaplerosis is the act of replenishing TCA cycle intermediates that have been extracted for biosynthesis (in what are called anaplerotic reactions).

choices.text: Is cofactor for pyruvate and alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

questions.text: Thiamine deficiency results in decrease energy production, because TPP interferes with
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Is cofactor for pyruvate and alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase Ref. Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th edition, Chapter 44, Page 556. Thiamin diphosphate is the coenzyme for three multienzyme complexes that catalyze oxidative decarboxylation reactions: pyruvate dehydrogenase in carbohydrate metabolism ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in the citric acid cycle and branched-chain keto-acid dehydrogenase involved in the metabolism of leucine, isoleucine, and valine In each case, the thiamine diphosphate provides a reactive carbon on the thiazole moiety that forms a carbanion, which then adds to the carbonyl group, eg, pyruvate. The addition compound is then decarboxylated, eliminating CO2. Thiamin diphosphate is also the coenzyme for transketolase, in the pentose phosphate pathway

questions.text: Phenylbutyrate is used in urea cycle disorders because it
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Scavenges nitrogen Ref. Textbook of biochemistry. Richard Harvey. Page. 256

questions.text: A young lady presented with tingling sensation in legs and hands. On examination she had fissure tongue and lesions in angle of mouth. On investigation, she had low RBC glutathione reductase activity. Diagnosis is deficiency of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Vitamin B2 Ref. Textbook of biochemistry. Richard Harvey. Page. 242 Riboflavin released by the catabolism of enzymes is rapidly incorporated into newly synthesized enzymes. Deficiency is characterized by cheilosis, desquamation and inflammation of the tongue, and a seborrheic dermatitis. Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

questions.text: Which of the yields 3 molecules of ATP under anearboic metabolism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Under anaerobic metabolism, the body generates energy without using oxygen, primarily through a process called glycolysis. In this process, glucose is broken down into pyruvate and then converted to lactate, producing a net gain of 2 ATP molecules per molecule of glucose or galactose. However, when glycogen is used instead of glucose, the situation is slightly different. Glycogen is a stored form of glucose found in the liver and muscles. When glycogen is broken down for energy, it enters glycolysis as glucose-1-phosphate, which is then converted to glucose-6-phosphate without using ATP. This bypasses the first step of glycolysis that normally consumes one ATP. As a result, the breakdown of glycogen under anaerobic conditions yields a net gain of 3 ATP molecules per glucose unit. Amino acids, on the other hand, are not a primary energy source during anaerobic metabolism, as they require oxygen-dependent pathways for efficient ATP production. Therefore, among the options given, glycogen is the only substrate that yields 3 molecules of ATP under anaerobic conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in low insulin-glucagon ratio?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Glycogen storage Ref. Harper Biochemistry 30th edition, Page. 188

choices.text: It does not depend on the macronutrients

questions.text: Thermogenic food is which of the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) High protein diet Diet induced thermogenesis (DIT) can be defined as the increase in energy expenditure above basal fasting level divided by the energy content of the food ingested and is commonly expressed as a percentage.This is the energy expended in the digestion, absorption, storage and subsequent processing of food. The main determinant of DIT is the energy content of the food, followed by the protein fraction of the food. The thermic effect of alcohol is similar to the thermic effect of protein.Reported DIT values for separate nutrients are 0 to 3% for fat, 5 to 10% for carbohydrate, 20 to 30% for protein, and 10 to 30% for alcohol. In healthy subjects with a mixed diet, DIT represents about 10% of the total amount of energy ingested over 24 h.

choices.text: Increased in activity of hepatic lipase
Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors
Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase
Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity

questions.text: In chronic diabetics the value of TG and VLDL are more because
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The main function of hormone-sensitive lipase is to mobilize the stored fats.[10] HSL functions to hydrolyze either a fatty acid from a triacylglycerol molecule, freeing a fatty acid and diglyceride, or a fatty acid from a diacylglycerol molecule, freeing a fatty acid and monoglyceride. HSL is activated when the body needs to mobilize energy stores, and so responds positively to catecholamines, ACTH. It is inhibited by insulin. Previously, glucagon was thought to activate HSL, however the removal of insulin's inhibitory effects ("cutting the brakes") is the source of activation.

questions.text: RFLP was used in-order to identify the five different species of staphylococci in a surgical ICU. Which of the following site does the restriction enzyme act?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) GATATC-CTATAG A palindromic sequence with 4-6 base pairs. Ref. Harper Biochemisty 30th edition. Page. 452

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding mitochondrial DNA?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mitochondrial DNA consists of the mitochondrial genome Double-stranded & circular Arranged into a single chromosome Composed of 0.25% of the cell's genetic makeup in animal cells Freely floating in the mitochondrial matrix Not enclosed by the nuclear envelope Size is 16.569 base pairs Not packed with histone proteins Consists of 37 genes, encoding 13 proteins, 22 (RNAs, and 2 rRNAs Lacks non-coding DNA regions like introns Replicated independently from DNA Maternally inherited

questions.text: Which is the best vial for sending a blood sample for serum electrolyte analysis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Green vial: This less commonly used bottle is for biochemistry tests which require heparinised plasma or whole blood for analysis. Additive: Heparin (Sodium/Lithium/Ammonium) What additive does: Inhibits thrombin formation to prevent clotting Laboratory uses: Chemistry Testing (Plasma determinations in chemistry): ammonia, carboxyhemoglobin& STAT electrolytes, chromosome screening, insulin, renin and aldosterone

questions.text: Which vitamin is required as cofactor for enzyme glycogen phosphorylase?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ref: 29th ed. Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, P.180 Pyridoxal phosphate uses Coenzyme in transamination and decarboxylation of amino acids and glycogen phosphorylase; modulation of steroid hormone action.

questions.text: A 6-years-old patient presented with fatigue on normal outdoor activity. In blood, there were raised triglycerides, ? cholesterol, fatty acids, lactate and blood sugar was 60 mg/dl. USG shows enlarged liver and kidney. Liver biopsy showed increased glycogen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref: 29th ed. Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, Page no. 181

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency department with prolonged starvation. Which of the following tests will be positive?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In starvation- rothera’s test is positive for ketone bodies Acetoacetic acid or acetone reacts with nitroprusside in alkaline solution to form a purple-colored complex.

questions.text: Which decreases affinity of oxygen with hemoglobin?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) An increase in hydrogen ion concentration (H?) leads to a decrease in pH (more acidic environment). This promotes the Bohr effect, which decreases the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, allowing more oxygen to be released to the tissues. This is crucial during high metabolic activity when tissues produce more CO? and H?. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Reduced 2,3 DPG Incorrect. 2,3-DPG (diphosphoglycerate) binds to hemoglobin and lowers its oxygen affinity. If 2,3-DPG is reduced, oxygen affinity actually increases, making it harder for hemoglobin to release oxygen. C. Increase in temperature Incorrect in the context of the question wording — because increased temperature also decreases hemoglobin's oxygen affinity. So this could seem correct, but A is more direct and fundamental via the Bohr effect. However, if multiple correct options were allowed, C would also be correct. D. High Altitudes Incorrect. At high altitudes, the body increases 2,3-DPG to help release oxygen more readily, but high altitude itself doesn't directly decrease oxygen affinity — it's the body's adaptive response that affects affinity. So it's not the most direct cause.

questions.text: Which amino acid is not formed by post translational modification?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ref: 29th ed. Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, Page no.269-270 and 489 Selenocysteine is not derived by post-translational modification, rather it is derived from co-translational modification of serine on a serylt-rna

questions.text: In SCID which type of DNA repair isdefective :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ref: Lippincott’s Illustrated Reviews: Cell and molecular Biology, Page no. 78-80

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which of the following substances will be found accumulated in the brain peroxisomes?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ref: 29th ed. Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry, Page no. 554 This condition is apparent at birth and is characterized by profound neurologic impairment, victims often dying within a year. The number of peroxisomes can vary from being almost normal to being virtually absent in some patients. Biochemical findings include an accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, abnormalities of the synthesis of bile acids, and a marked reduction of plasmalogens. The condition is usually caused by mutations in genes encoding certain proteins—the PEX family of genes, also called peroxins —involved in various steps of peroxisome biogenesis, or in genes encoding certain peroxisomal enzymes themselves.

questions.text: Mutation in hartnup disease:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hartnups disease is an autosomal recessive disease in which there is mutation of neutral amino acid transporters in GIT mucosa and in PCT of nephron. Gene mutation responsible of this condition is SLC6A19.

questions.text: Which type of bonds are represented by the dotted lines in the image:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) DNA base pairing between complementary deoxynucleotides involves the formation of hydrogen bonds. Two such H-bonds form between adenine and thymine, and three H-bonds form between cytidine and guanine. The broken lines represent H-bonds

choices.text: Abnormal test rules out primary intestinal malabsorption

questions.text: False statement regarding Schilling test is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Schillings test is done to find out cause of vit B12 deficiency in the body. The Schilling test is a medical investigation used for patients with vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency. The purpose of the test is to determine how well the patient is able to absorb B12 from their intestinal tract.

questions.text: True about telomerase is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Telomerase is an enzyme which prevents end shortening in the daughter dna after replication. This enzyme is a ribonucleo protein which consists of a protein body which has reverse transcriptase activity and a rna template. It produces a telomere at the end of daughter dna

questions.text: Odd chain fatty acids can form glucose by which pathway?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Odd chain fatty acids oxidation gives an end product propionyl CoA which is a gluconeogenic substrate. Propionyl CoA converts into succinyl CoA and then converted into glucose by gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: Hershey chase experiment was done on:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The Hershey–Chase experiments were a series of experiments conducted in 1952 by Alfred Hershey and Martha Chase that helped to confirm that DNA is genetic material. Hershey and Chase showed that when bacteriophages, which are composed of DNA and protein, infect bacteria, their DNA enters the host bacterial cell, but most of their protein does not.

questions.text: Vitamin C cannot be produced in humans due to lack of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Due to lack of L-gulonolactone oxidase, Vit-C cannot be synthesised in human body by uronic acid pathway. In humans , uronic acid pathway produces glucuronic acid which is a component of mucopolysaccharides and also helps in conjugation reactions. Essential pentosuria is associated with defect in this pathway, where L – Xylulose comes out in urine due to lack of L-Xylulose reductase enzyme

questions.text: Klenow fragment lacks the activity of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Kornberg enzyme is DNA polymerase I discovered by Kornberg in 1957. It has 3 catalytic activities 5’ -3’ polymerase activity 3’ – 5’ exonuclease activity 5’ – 3’ exonuclease activity The larger fragment of this enzyme shows the propeeties similar to DNA polymerase III ie 5’ -3’ polymerase activity 3’ – 5’ exonuclease activity And he named this as klenow fragment

questions.text: Which of the following cell organelles are involved in I cell disease
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) I cell disease is a condition in which the lysosomal enzymes which are synthesized in rough endoplasmic reticulum, do not reach the lysosomes. This occurs due to defect in post translational modification of those enzymes and due to lack of N-acetyl glucosamine transferase enzyme in golgi bodies. In this disease the lysosomes are empty and thus the particles reachin lysosomes are not destroyed. They accumulate in the form of inclusion bodies and are seen in skeletal muscle biopsy.

questions.text: Name the disease where limit dextrin is deposited in liver
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cori’s disease is a type III glycogen storage disease in which de branching enxyme is deficient.

questions.text: Which of the disease have defect in acid lipase
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pompe’s disease is a type II glycogen storage disorder which is also a lysosomal storage disorder. Cardiomyopathy can be a feature of this disease

questions.text: Which of the following is a Zinc containing enzyme
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Carbonic anhydrase enzyme requires Zinc.

questions.text: Injection of heparin releases
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lipoprotein lipase enzyme is present in the capillary endothelium. It is adherent to the capillary wall with the helpof heparin sulphate. Injection heparin will break this association and hence causes release of lipoprotein lipase in the blood

questions.text: Alpha oxidation defect in Refsum disease associated with
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Refsums disease in condition in which alpha oxidation of branched chain fatty acids is defective.

questions.text: Basophilic stippling of RBCseen in which enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lead intoxication is accompanied by an acquired deficiency of erythrocyte pryimidinespecific, 5'-nucleotidase. Genetically determined deficiency of this enzyme is associated with chronic hemolysis, marked basophilic stippling of erythrocytes on stained blood films, and unique intraerythrocytic accumulations of pyrimidine-containing nucleotides. The present report documents that lead-induced deficiency when sufficiently severe gives rise to findings similar to the hereditary disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is based on RNA?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) RT-PCR stands for reverse transcriptase PCR. This is a process of synthesising DNA from RNA using reverse transcriptase enzyme.

questions.text: Which of the following does not require 5’ capping?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Capping is a process which protects 5' end of mRNA and polyadenylation protects 3' end against the action of exonucleases. mRNA, snRNA and siRNA undergo this process but tRNA and rRNA are relatively stable. Hence, they do not undergo capping at the 5' end.

questions.text: Uncouplers of oxidative phosphorylation include?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B, E) Ref: Harper 30th Ed/132; Satyanaryan 4th Ed/233-34 Explanation: Uncouplers of oxidative phosphorylation(Allow oxidation of substrates without ATP formation) 2,4-Dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP) Dinitrocresol Aspirin (high dose) Trifluorocarbonylcyanidephenylhydrazone(TCCP), Chlorocarbonylcyanidephenylhydrazone (CCCP) Antibiotics: Valinomycin, Gramicidin A and Nigercin Physiological uncouplers: High concentrations of thermogenin, thyroxine and long chain FFAs

questions.text: In a reaction substrate is available in a concentration that is 1000 times the Km value of the enzyme. After 9 minutes of reaction, 1% substrate is converted to product (12 microgram/ml). If the concentration of the enzyme is changed to 1/3 and concentration of substrate is doubled. What is the time taken to convert the substrate into the same amount of product, i.e. 12 microgram/ml?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) When substrate is not the limiting factor, the velocity of the reaction is directly proportional to the enzyme concentration. When enzyme is reduced to 1/3rd then to get the same amount of product, the time takes is 3 times more than before 9x3 = 27 min

questions.text: Fe absorption increases by which vitamin?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vit-C / ascorbic acid is an anti oxidant. It converts ferric ion to ferrous ion with the help of enzyme cytochrome b reductase in GIT and increases the absorption of iron.

questions.text: Co-factors needed for biosynthesis of fatty acids include(s)?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A,B,C,E) Ref: Harper 31st Ed Explanation: Fatty acid biosynthesis cofactors are NADPH ATP Mn2+ Biotin HCO3- Basic building block is Acetyl CoA

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme activity decreases in fasting?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Both C and D are correct answers. D is better answer Acetyl CaA carboxylase enzyme is a rate limiting enzyme of fatty acid synthesis. It requires presence of insulin to undergo dephosphorylation to become active. In fasting state, insulin is absent. Hence activity of this enzyme is absent. Phosphofructokinase I (PFK I) : in fasting state, the level of fructose 2,6 bisphosphate which is a positive allosteric modifier of PFKI reduces. Hence activity of PFK I is also reduced.

choices.text: Acts as an acceptor for amino acids in protein synthesis

questions.text: True statement(s) regarding tRNA is/are?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B,D,E) Ref: Harper’s 30th Ed/394 Explanation: Structure of tRNA Has a clover leaf structure Acceptor arm consists of a CCA tail, which serves as AA attachment site Anticodon has a sequence complementary to codon Attaches to ribosomes by its T ¥ C arm

questions.text: An adolescent male patient came with pain in calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy excessive amount of glycogen present was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Muscle phosphorylase enzyme deficiency is seen in Mc ardle’s disease. Since the presentation is late in this patient option A is ruled out.

questions.text: Fluoride released from fluoroacetate inhibits which metabolic pathway?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fluroacetate binds with oxaloacetate with the help of enzyme citate synthase to form flurocitrate. Flurocitrate competes with aconitase enzyme and inhibits the TCA cycle.

questions.text: Examples of chaperon include all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (CE) Ref: Harper 30th Ed/609 Explanation: Chaperone proteins Present in prokaryotes as well as eukaryotes Induced by heat, stress or acidosis Bind to hydrophobic regions of unfolded and aggregated proteins and act as a quality control or editing mechanism for detecting misfolded proteins Most show ATPase activity Found in cytosol, mitochondria and endoplasmic reticulum lumen Examples include Heat shock proteins, Calnexin, calreticulin, BiP, GRP94, PDI, PPI

questions.text: Vitamin K in its coenzyme form is regenerated by which enzyme?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Epoxide reductase enzyme converts VitK hydroquinone to vit K epoxide. Which is then converted to Vit K quinone.

questions.text: Vitamin E deficiency in adult causes?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A,B,C,D,E) Ref: Harper 30th Ed/553 Explanation: Features of Vitamin E deficiency Neuromuscular problems – such as spinocerebellar ataxia and myopathies. Neurological problems – may include dysarthria, absence of deep tendon reflexes, loss of the ability to sense vibration and detect where body parts are in three dimensional space, and positive Babinski sign. Hemolyticanemia – due to oxidative damage to red blood cells Retinopathy Impairment of the immune response

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon shown below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) β-galactosidase is a protein encoded by the lacZ gene of the lac operon, and it exists as a homotetramer in its active state. However, a mutant β-galactosidase derived from the M15 strain of E. coli has its N-terminal residues 11—41 deleted and this mutant, the ω-peptide, is unable to form a tetramer and is inactive. This mutant form of protein however may return fully to its active tetrameric state in the presence of an N-terminal fragment of the protein, the α-peptide. The rescue of function of the mutant β-galactosidase by the α-peptide is called α-complementation.

questions.text: Best investigation for metabolic disorder is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tandem mass spectrometry, also known as MS/MS or MS2, is a technique in instrumental analysis where two or more mass analyzers are coupled together using an additional reaction step to increase their abilities to analyse chemical samples. A common use of tandem MS is the analysis of biomolecules, such as proteins and peptides. Newborn screening is the process of testing newborn babies for treatable genetic, endocrinologic, metabolic and hematologic diseases. The development of tandem mass spectrometry screening in the early 1990s led to a large expansion of potentially detectable congenital metabolic diseases that affect blood levels of organic acids.

questions.text: Vitamin C deficiency is associated with?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (ABCE) Ref: Harper 30th Ed/561-65 Explanation: Features of Vitamin C deficiency (Scurvy) Constitutional symptoms: Low grade fever, malaise, irritability, weakness, low appetite, weight loss Gum bleeds, petechiae, ecchymosis and perifollicular hemorrhages Epistaxis Anemia Defective dentition Poor wound healing Low immunity Scorbutic rosary: Tender Brittle bones Generalised tenderness and pseudoparalysis in young children

questions.text: Which is/are not transport proteins?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B,D) Explanation: Collagen is a structural protein whereas Ferritin is a storage protein as well as an acute phase protein.

choices.text: White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.text: An infant presented to the OPD with a history of vomiting and malnutrition. On investigation the Guthrie test was found to be positive. All are true regarding this disease except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Phenylketonuria Occurs due to deficiency of phenyl alanine hydroxylase enzyme. White patch of hair is due to TYROSINE deficiency. Urinary excretion products are: phenyl pyruvate, phenyl lactate, phenyl acetate.

questions.text: Full form of LCAT is -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref: Harper 30th Ed/272 Explanation: Lecithin–cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT, also called phosphatidylcholine–sterol O-acyltransferase) is an enzymethat converts free cholesterol into cholesteryl ester (a more hydrophobic form of cholesterol), which is then sequestered into the core of a lipoprotein particle.

questions.text: Best method to measure HbA1c?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Affinity chromatography Affinity chromatography is considered one of the most accurate and commonly used methods for measuring HbA1c. It separates glycated hemoglobin from non-glycated hemoglobin based on the specific interaction between the glycated hemoglobin and the chromatographic medium, making it a highly specific and reliable method. Why the others are less appropriate: A. Isoelectric focusing: This method separates proteins based on their charge and is not as precise for measuring HbA1c compared to affinity chromatography, as it is more used for separating different hemoglobin variants or other proteins. C. Ion exchange chromatography: This method can also be used for HbA1c testing but is less specific than affinity chromatography and may have some limitations in separating HbA1c from other forms of hemoglobin or dealing with hemoglobin variants. D. Electrophoresis: This method separates proteins based on their charge and is not typically used for HbA1c quantification. While electrophoresis can detect HbA1c, it is not as reliable or accurate for routine measurement as affinity chromatography.

questions.text: Which among the following organs cannot use ketone bodies?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B,E) Ref: Harper 30th Ed/227 Explanation: Liver and RBCs can not utilize ketone bodies.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Respiratory quotient= CO2 produced/ 02 consumed RQ of various macronutrients are as follows carbohydrate = 1 fat = 0.7 protein = 0.8 mixed diet = 0.85 Alcohol = 0.66

questions.text: Fastest way to re-generate ATP during exercise
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) ADP + Creatine phosphate ( phosphagen) = ATP + Creatine this reaction is catalysed by the enzyme creatine phosphokinase

questions.text: Which among the following fragments will be found maximally towards the negative pole during DNA gel electrophoresis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Explanation: DNA itself is negatively charged and when gel electrophoresis is done, the largest fragment will move most slowly and hence will be found maximally towards the negative side.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Northern blotting is done to quantify Gene expression in a cell

questions.text: Substrate(s) for gluconeogenesis may include?

questions.text: Alcoholic hepatitis, which of the following elevation is most characteristic
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Gamma glutamyl transferase present in biliray canaliculus is increased in alcoholic hepatitis

questions.text: Action of Thyroid hormones T3 and T4 on thyroid hormone receptors is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Receptors for T3 and T4 are present inside the nucleus. thyroid hormone receptors are heterodimers which binds to DNA and controls the expression of genes

questions.text: Pyridoxine is needed for?

questions.text: True regarding Okazaki fragments are? A. Formed on both leading and lagging strand B. Requires DNA polymerase C. Requires helicase to separate the two strands before Okazaki fragment forms D. Synthesized continually E. Synthesized discontinuously
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ref: Harper 30th Ed/383

questions.text: Ketogenic amino acids include(s)?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A,B,D) Purely ketogenic amino acid: leucine Both glucogenic and ketogenic amino acids: phenylalanine, isoleucine, tyrosine, tryptophan, lysine Rest of the amino acids are purely glucogenic.

questions.text: True about DNA polymerase I activity?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A,B,E) DNA Pol I possesses four enzymatic activities: A 5'→3' (forward) DNA-dependent DNA polymerase activity, requiring a 3' primer site and a template strand A 3'→5' (reverse) exonuclease activity that mediates proofreading A 5'→3' (forward) exonuclease activity mediating nick translation during DNA repair. A 5'→3' (forward) RNA-dependent DNA polymerase activity. Pol I operates on RNA templates with considerably lower efficiency (0.1–0.4%) than it does DNA templates, and this activity is probably of only limited biological significance

questions.text: Hyperuricemia is present in which among the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A,D) HGPRTase deficiency causes Lesch nyhan syndrome which is characterised by self mutilation. Deficiency of this enzyme increses hypoxanthine and guanine which are substrates for formation of uric acid leading to hyperuricemia. Excessive PRPP synthase produces more PRPP. This inturn leads to increased purine synthesis. Excessive purine metabolism leads to formation of uric acid leading to hyperuricemia.

questions.text: Stop codons include(s)?

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding vitamin K, except-

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Normally, concentration of LDH-1 is lower than LDH-2, but after myocardial infarction, LDH-1 concentration becomes elevated and exceeds the concentration of LDH-2. This phenomenon is called a flipped LDH pattern.

Actions: Removal of Primers and filling of Gap, DNA proof reading , DNA repair ( major). -DNAP-II : DNA proof reading & DNA repair ( minor) - DNAP-III : Leading Strand Synthesis, Okazaki fragment synthesis, DNA proof reading. questions.text: Which of the following X-linked disorder-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Red–green color blindness, a very common trait in humans and frequently used to explain X-linked disorders.[8] Between seven and ten percent of men and 0.49% to 1% of women are affected. Its commonness may be explained by its relatively benign nature. It is also known as daltonism.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is not lost in cystinuria-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In cystinuria type I, all four amino acids—cystine, lysine, arginine, and ornithine—are excreted in the urine in high concentration

questions.text: In fish odor disease which of the following vitamin intake is restricted-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Normal individuals can smell of rotting fish if 20 g of pure choline is given to them orally. 10 This is because of the resultant excessive production of trimethylamine, which exceeds the capacity of the normal healthy liver to oxidise it to a non-odorous oxide.

questions.text: PKa of a drug is equal to the pH when
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) pKa is defined as pH at which 50% of the drug is in ionized state and 50% is in unionized state. Maximum buffering action of any molecule is seen when its pKa=pH.

questions.text: Methylation of cytosine is associated with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cytosine methylation is a common form of post-replicative DNA modification seen in both bacteria and eukaryotes. Modified cytosines have long been known to act as hotspots for mutations due to the high rate of spontaneous deamination of this base to thymine, resulting in a G/T mismatch.

questions.text: Urea, creatinine and nitric oxide are formed by which amino acid?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) -Metabolic functions of Arginine : Synthesis of A) Agmatine : Antihypertensive B) Creatine : Glycine + Arginine + Methionine C) Urea D) Ornithine E) Nitric oxide

questions.text: Which of the following is not the source of cytosolic NADPH
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A. Isocitrate dehydrogenase (ICDH): The cytosolic isoform of isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH1) is an NADP+-dependent enzyme that catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of isocitrate to α-ketoglutarate, producing NADPH in the process. Therefore, it is a source of cytosolic NADPH. B. ATP citrate lyase: This enzyme is found in the cytosol and cleaves citrate into acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate, a crucial step for fatty acid synthesis. While it provides acetyl-CoA, which is eventually used in a pathway that consumes NADPH (fatty acid synthesis), ATP citrate lyase itself does not directly produce NADPH. Instead, the oxaloacetate produced can be converted to malate and then by malic enzyme (Option C) to pyruvate, generating NADPH. However, ATP citrate lyase is not the direct generator of NADPH. C. Malic enzyme: The cytosolic NADP+-dependent malic enzyme catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of malate to pyruvate, generating NADPH and carbon dioxide. This enzyme is a significant source of cytosolic NADPH, particularly in lipogenic tissues. Therefore, it is a source of cytosolic NADPH. D. G6PD (Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase): This is the first and rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP), which occurs in the cytosol. G6PD catalyzes the oxidation of glucose-6-phosphate to 6-phosphogluconolactone, reducing NADP+ to NADPH. The PPP is a major source of cytosolic NADPH. Therefore, it is a source of cytosolic NADPH.

questions.text: Hyperammonemia inhibits TCA cycle by inhibiting ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) One effect of ammonia is the inhibition of the rate limiting TCA cycle enzyme alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (alphaKGDH) and possibly also pyruvate dehydrogenase, but this has been regarded to be of no quantitative importance. However, recent studies justify a revision of this point of view. Based on published data, the following sequence of events is proposed. Inhibition of alphaKGDH both enhances the detoxification of ammonia by formation of glutamine from alpha-ketoglutarate and reduces the rate of NADH and oxidative ATP production in astrocytic mitochondria. In the astrocytic cytosol this will lead to formation of lactate even in the presence of sufficient oxygen supply

questions.text: LCAT deficiency increases which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In LCAT (Lecithin–Cholesterol Acyltransferase) deficiency, the enzyme responsible for converting free cholesterol into cholesteryl esters is absent or non-functional. This disrupts the normal maturation of HDL particles, leading to a marked decrease in HDL levels. LDL levels are typically normal or reduced, since the conversion of VLDL to LDL is also affected. However, due to impaired metabolism and clearance, VLDL levels tend to increase. This occurs because LCAT plays a role in remodeling triglyceride-rich lipoproteins like VLDL, and without it, VLDL clearance is inefficient, leading to its accumulation. Chylomicrons are usually not significantly affected in LCAT deficiency. Therefore, among the given options, the most likely to be increased is VLDL.

questions.text: A 25 yr old alcoholic presented with edema, hypertension, ocular disturbances and altered mental status. Diagnosis of wet beri beri with high output cardiac failure wasmade. This is due to deficiency of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Wet Beri Beri : Associated symptoms are : 1) High output cardiac failure 2) Dyspnea 3) Cardiomegaly 4) Peripheral edema 5) Pulmonary edema Dry Beri Beri: Peripheral nervous system affected. - Symmetric motor and Sensory neuropathy. - Pain , Paresthesia, loss of Reflexes especially in lower limbs , muscle cramps , muscle atrophy .

questions.text: Increased glutamine in blood, urine and CSF is due to deficiency of ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: True about type I diabetes mellitus is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) -Insulin is an anabolic hormone , so stimulates Protein & Fat synthesis. So in Type 1 diabetes Mellitus where there is Absolute insulin deficiency, there ka increased Lipolysis and Protein breakdown. -The liver exhibits a decrease in gluconeogenesis and increases in glycogenesis in response to the presence of insulin.

questions.text: Protein which is not synthesised in liver is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The dictum is : All proteins are synthesized in liver except Immunoglobulins . Immunoglobulins are also called Gamma Globulins .

questions.text: Which of the following is not a ribozyme?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Some examples of naturally occurring ribozymes include: RNase P. Peptidyl transferase 23S rRNA. GIR1 branching ribozyme. Leadzyme. Group I and Group II introns. Hairpin ribozyme. Hammerhead ribozyme. HDV ribozyme.

questions.text: Type I hyperlipoproteinemia is characterised by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: The linking compound between kreb’s cycle and urea cycle is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)
